did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia Mineralogy Department records

bioghist.p: Not long after it opened in 1812, a cabinet of minerals was established at the Academy of Natural Sciences. Several of the founders and early members of the Academy assembled private mineral collections, some of which were later donated to the Academy. The Mineralogical and Geological Section was established in 1877 and dissolved in 1924. One of the department's members was Samuel George Gordon, who joined the Academy as a Jessup scholarship student and, over his career, became one of the noted mineralogists of his day.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Department of Mineralogy of the Academy of Natural Sciences. These records, from the office of Robert Middleton, John Sherman, and others, include correspondence, memos, reports, documents related to fundraising, lists of specimens in various collections, reprints, records of exhibits, records of loans, and materials related to hiring curatorial staff. Catalogs in the collection include those of the Vaux, Seybert, Fiss, Keeley collections. There are also checklists of specimens and discrepancy forms for the mineralogy collections, notes and research materials for a history of the mineralogy collection at the Academy. The collection also includes published volumes (Mineralogy, by Berry & Mason, 1959, and Mineralogy of Pennsylvania, Montgomery, 1969); mineralogical assay tools; awards from the Tuscarora Lapidary Society, sponsors of "Gemarama," 1973, 1978, and 1979; Samuel G. Gordon's collection of glass and film slides of geologic formations, landscapes, and portraits; glass slides of colored photomicrographs of mineral preparations; an oversize map of a mineralogy collection cabinet layout; and a small model of mine tram car.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
